title: OverTheWire Bandit: Complete Walkthrough
description: Practice Linux command line and security fundamentals through OverTheWire's Bandit wargame. Each level teaches essential hacking and system administration skills.

content.text: OverTheWire Bandit is a wargame designed to teach Linux command line basics and security concepts. Each level requires you to find a password to access the next level, progressively building your skills.
In this tutorial, we'll work through the levels, explaining not just the solution but the underlying concepts and tools you'll use.

content.title: What You'll Learn
items: Linux command line navigation and file operations
Text processing with grep, find, and pipes

content.text: Level 0: The goal of this level is to log into the game using SSH. The host is bandit.labs.overthewire.org on port 2220.
Once connected, you'll see a welcome message. You're now in the Bandit Level 0 shell! The password for the next level is stored in a file called readme in the home directory.

content.title: Challenge
content.text: Find and read the readme file to get the password for Level 1. Use the 'ls' command to list files and 'cat' to display file contents.
Log in to Level 1 using the password you found. The password for the next level is stored in a file called - located in the home directory.
The challenge here is that - is interpreted by the shell as stdin. Simply using 'cat -' won't work. We need to specify the file path explicitly:

content.title: Key Concept: Special Characters
items: The dash (-) is treated specially by most commands

content.title: Challenge
content.text: Read the file named '-' and retrieve the password for Level 2. Remember to use ./ before the filename.
The password for the next level is stored in a file called spaces in this filename located in the home directory.
Spaces in filenames require special handling. You have several options:

content.code:
# Method 1: Escape spaces with backslash
cat spaces\ in\ this\ filename

# Method 2: Use quotes
cat "spaces in this filename"

# Method 3: Tab completion
cat spa<TAB>

content.title: Pro Tip
items: Tab completion is your friend - type the first few characters and press TAB
The shell will automatically escape spaces for you
Double quotes preserve spaces and special characters

content.text: The password is stored in a hidden file in the inhere directory.
In Linux, files starting with a dot (.) are hidden by default. To see them, use the -a flag with ls:
The -l flag gives a detailed listing, and -a shows all files including hidden ones. You should see a file named .hidden:

content.title: Understanding ls Flags
items: -a: Show all files, including hidden ones
-l: Long format with permissions, size, dates

content.text: The password is in the only human-readable file in the inhere directory. There are 10 files, but only one contains ASCII text.
Use the file command to identify file types:
The file command analyzes content and tells you the file type. Look for "ASCII text" in the output. Once identified, cat that specific file:

content.title: Challenge
content.text: Use the 'file' command to identify which of the 10 files contains human-readable text, then retrieve the password.

chapters.title: Level 5 → Level 6: Finding Files by Properties

content.text: The password is stored somewhere in the inhere directory with these properties: human-readable, 1033 bytes in size, and not executable.
The find command is perfect for this. It can search by size, permissions, and other criteria:

content.title: Understanding Find Flags
items: -type f: Only find regular files (not directories)

content.text: Once you've located the file, use cat to read it and get the password.
The password is stored somewhere on the server with these properties: owned by user bandit7, owned by group bandit6, and 33 bytes in size.
This time we need to search the entire system, not just our home directory:
The 2>/dev/null redirects error messages (like permission denied) to /dev/null, making the output cleaner.

content.title: Understanding Redirection
items: /dev/null is a black hole that discards data
This prevents permission denied errors from cluttering output

chapters.title: Level 7 → Level 8: Grep for Pattern Matching

content.text: The password is in the file data.txt next to the word "millionth".
Use grep to search for text patterns within files:
Grep searches for the pattern and returns matching lines. This is much faster than manually reading through a large file.

content.title: Challenge
content.text: Use grep to find the password in data.txt. Try combining grep with other commands using pipes to process the output further.
